choices.text: Only healthcare professionals can file complaints
The person with mental illness or their nominated representative has the right to make complaints
The concerned Board can file complaints on behalf of the person with mental illness
Only legal guardians can make complaints

questions.text: Who has the right to make complaints about deficiencies in the provision of mental health services?
questions.solution:
Overview of MHCA 2017:

  • Date Passed: 7th April 2017.
  • Objective: To provide mental healthcare services and protect the rights of persons with mental illness (PMI).
  • Differences from 1987 Act:
    • No consideration for treatment choice or consent.
    • No rehabilitation provisions.

Main Features:

  • Protects the rights of PMI (e.g., dignity, access to care).
  • Based on the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities.

Chapters of the Act:

  1. Preliminary: Definitions.
  2. Mental Illness & Capacity: Defines mental illness and decision-making capacity.
  3. Advance Directives (AD): Guidelines for creating ADs about treatment preferences.
  4. Nominated Representatives: Appointment of representatives for decision-making.
  5. Rights of PMI: Right to care, dignity, non-discrimination, and legal aid.
  6. Government Duties: Responsibilities of the government for mental health services.
  7. Central & State Mental Health Authorities: Oversight and policy implementation.
  8. Mental Health Establishments: Regulations for mental health facilities.
  9. Mental Health Review Board: Reviews compliance with the Act and protects PMI rights.
  10. Admission, Treatment, and Discharge: Admission procedures, treatment rights, and discharge processes.
  11. Responsibilities of Other Agencies: Involvement of police, prisons, and other agencies in mental health care.
  12. Offences & Penalties: Penalties for violating the Act.
  13. Miscellaneous: Other legal provisions.

questions.text: What is the maximum duration of emergency treatment a person with mental illness can receive under the Mental Health Care Act, 2017?
questions.solution:
• Emergency treatment can be provided for up to 72 hours, with the consent of the nominated representative (if available).
  • Mental Health Review Board:
    • Consists of 6 members, including a District Judge (Chairperson), psychiatrists, medical practitioners, and representatives from mental health NGOs or caregivers.
    • Functions include registering and modifying advance directives (AD), adjudicating complaints about care deficiencies, and inspecting facilities (including prisons).
  • Admission and Treatment:
    • Independent admission(Sec 85): For individuals who are capable of making decisions or need minimal support.
    • Admission of minors(Sec 87): Requires application by a nominated representative and evaluation by two psychiatrists.
    • Supported admission(Sec 89-90): For individuals who require more intensive support for up to 30 days or longer.
  • Emergency Treatment(Sec 94):
    • Can be provided by any medical practitioner for up to 72 hours, with the informed consent of the nominated representative (NR), if available.
  • Responsibilities of Other Agencies:
    • Police and Magistrates: Must intervene if a person with mental illness is neglected, abused, or requires care.
    • Prisoners with Mental Illness: Special provisions for the admission and care of prisoners with mental illness.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Emergency treatment can be provided for up to 72 hours, with the consent of the nominated representative (if available).

questions.text: What is the age range of juveniles who may be tried as adults for heinous offences under the JJ Act 2015?
questions.solution:
Juveniles aged 16-18 years who commit heinous offences may be tried as adults under the JJ Act 2015, depending on the nature of the crime.

Juvenile Justice (JJ) Act, 2015:

  • Purpose: To consolidate and amend the law regarding children in conflict with the law and children in need of care and protection.
  • Enacted On: 7th May 2015 (Lok Sabha), 22nd December 2015 (Rajya Sabha).
  • Introduced by: Maneka Gandhi, Ministry of Women and Child Development.
  • Territorial Extent: Applies throughout India, except Jammu and Kashmir.

Juveniles in Conflict with Law:

  • Juvenile Justice Boards (JJBs) will be set up in each district.
    • Composition: Metropolitan or Judicial Magistrate and two social workers, including one woman.
  • Categories of Offences:
    1. Heinous Offences: Punishment of 7 years or more under IPC.
    2. Serious Offences: Punishment between 3-7 years.
    3. Petty Offences: Punishment below 3 years.

Punishments for Juveniles:

  • Juveniles can be kept in a special home for a maximum of 3 years.
  • 16-18 years: Juveniles committing heinous offences can be tried as adults.
  • A juvenile who commits a serious offence and is apprehended after the age of 21 may also be tried as an adult.

Procedure for Heinous Offences:

  • For juveniles apprehended before 21, a preliminary inquiry is conducted to assess mental/physical capacity.
    • Options for Juvenile: Counselling, community service, or referral to a Children's Court.
  • Juveniles between 16-18 years who commit serious or heinous offences may face the following:
    • Serious offences (under 21): Counselling, fine, or a maximum of 3 years in a special home.
    • Heinous offences (under 21): May be tried as a child (max 3 years) or an adult (life sentence).

Key Provisions:

  • Heinous Offence: Juveniles between 16-18 years may be tried as adults if they commit a heinous offence.
  • Serious Offence: Juveniles apprehended after the age of 21 for serious offences will be tried as adults.
  • JJB's Role: The JJB conducts inquiries, determines punishment, and ensures the rehabilitation and protection of the child's rights.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Categories of Offences:

  • Heinous Offences: Punishment of 7 years or more under IPC.
  • Serious Offences: Punishment between 3-7 years.
  • Petty Offences: Punishment below 3 years.

questions.text: What is the age limit for a child as defined under the POCSO Act, 2012?
questions.solution:
POCSO Act, 2012

  • Enacted: The POCSO Act was passed by the Indian Parliament in May 2012 and came into force on 14th November 2012.
  • Purpose: Protects children under the age of 18 from sexual offences such as sexual assault, sexual harassment, and pornography.
  • Gender Neutral: The Act is applicable to both boys and girls.
  • Key Definitions: The Act defines sexual offences broadly, not limited to rape.
  • Special Courts: Special Courts are established for the trial of cases under the Act to ensure child-sensitive adjudication.

Offences and Punishments under POCSO Act

  • Penetrative Sexual Assault(Section 3):
    • Punishment: Imprisonment for a minimum of 10 years to life, plus fine.
  • Aggravated Penetrative Sexual Assault(Section 5):
    • Punishment: Minimum 20 years to life imprisonment, plus fine.
  • Sexual Assault(Section 7):
    • Punishment: 5 to 7 years imprisonment, plus fine.
  • Sexual Harassment(Section 11):
    • Punishment: Up to 3 years imprisonment, plus fine.
  • Child Pornography(Section 13):
    • Punishment:
      1. First Conviction: Up to 5 years imprisonment, plus fine.
      2. Subsequent Conviction: 7 years imprisonment.
    • Storage of Child Pornography(Section 15):
      • Punishment: Fine and imprisonment up to 3 years for first-time offenders; higher penalties for repeat offences.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Protects children under the age of 18 from sexual offences such as sexual assault, sexual harassment, and pornography.

questions.text: According to the RPwD Act, 2016, what is the percentage of reservation in government jobs for persons with disabilities, including those with mental illness?
questions.solution:
The RPwD Act mandates 4% reservation in government and government-aided jobs for persons with disabilities, including those with mental illness, autism, specific learning disabilities, and intellectual disabilities.

RPwD Act, 2016

  • Introduction to RPwD Act:
    • India's ratification of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (UNCRPD) led to the RPwD Act, 2016.
    • Replaces the Persons with Disabilities Act, 1995 (PwD Act).
    • Moves from a charity-based modelto a rights-based model.
  • Definition of Disability:
    • Person with Disability (PwD) includes those with long-term physical, mental, intellectual, or sensory impairments.
    • These impairments interact with barriers in society, preventing equal participation.
  • Categories of Disability:
    • Mental Retardation: Significant limitation in intellectual functioning and adaptive behaviour (includes autism and specific learning disabilities).
    • Mental Illness: Substantial disorder affecting thinking, mood, memory, and behaviour (does not include mental retardation).
  • Key Provisions of the RPwD Act:
    • Ensures free healthcare and income-based services.
    • Introduces the right to legal capacity: PwDs can own property, control finances, and inherit assets.
    • Facilitates improved accessibility to votingand legal guardianship
  • Employment Reservations:
    • 4% reservation for PwDs in government and government-aided jobs, including mental illness, autism, SLD, and intellectual disability.
    • 1% reservation within this for specific disabilities (e.g., mental illness, autism, etc.).
  • Educational Provisions:
    • 5% reservation in high schools and higher education for students with disabilities.
    • Age relaxation of 5 years for PwDs in higher education.
  • Punishments for Atrocities Against PwDs:
    • Section 92 of the Act lists punishments for crimes against PwDs, including:
      1. Assault, denial of food or fluids, and sexual exploitation of PwDs.
      2. Disability-related discriminationor intentional harm to PwDs is punishable.
    • Key Rights and Provisions:
      • 5% reservationin poverty alleviation schemes and housing.
      • Provisions to retain jobs for employees who acquire a disability during service, particularly in cases of mental illness.
      • Legal safeguards against discrimination and exploitation.
    • Changes from Previous Legislation:
      • 1% reservation for PwDs in government jobs under the PwD Act is expanded to 4% under the RPwD Act.
      • 5% reservation in educational institutions, including higher education and agriculture schemes.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The RPwD Act mandates 4% reservation in government and government-aided jobs for persons with disabilities, including those with mental illness, autism, specific learning disabilities, and intellectual disabilities.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is NOT included in the list of drugs that a registered medical practitioner can hold for emergency use under the NDPS Act?
questions.solution:
According to the NDPS rules, a registered medical practitioner can hold Morphine, Codeine, Fentanyl, and Oxycodone (among other drugs) for emergency purposes without special authorization. However, Hydrocodone is not listed in the same category.

Opioids in Palliative Care

  • Drugs under NDPS Act used in palliative care: Morphine, Methadone, Codeine, Hydrocodone, Oxycodone, Fentanyl.
  • Primary Use: These opioids are used to manage severe pain in palliative care patients.
  1. Risks of Opioid Use
  • Opioid Addiction:
    • Prescription drug abuse is rising, leading to opioid addiction.
    • Symptoms of abuse: Intoxication (drowsiness, slurred speech, respiratory depression) and withdrawal (diarrhea, nausea, restlessness, cravings).
  • Legal Implications: Unauthorized use or prescription can lead to legal consequences under the NDPS Act.

choices.text: The participant's ability to freely make decisions without external interference
The participant's ability to understand the information provided and form a reasonable judgment
The participant's understanding of the risks and benefits of the research
The participant's willingness to participate in the research study

questions.text: Which of the following best describes capacity in the context of informed consent?
questions.solution:
INFORMED CONSENT:

  • Definition: Informed consent is an autonomous decision made by an individual regarding medical interventions or research participation.
  • Primary Aims: Ensuring individual autonomy and rational decision-making.
  • Dimensions: Clinical, ethical, and legal aspects of the intervention.
  • MHCA, 2017: Section 22 outlines required information for individuals with mental illness (PMI) when giving consent.

Types of Consent:

  1. Informed vs. Real Consent:
    • Informed: Full understanding of diagnosis, risks, and prognosis.
    • Real: In line with the "prudent person rule" (reasonable doctor’s judgment).
  2. Implicit vs. Explicit Consent:
    • Implicit: Implied through actions (e.g., showing up for examination).
    • Explicit: Clearly expressed, either verbal or written.

Option A: The participant's ability to freely make decisions without external interference.

This refers to voluntariness, not capacity. Voluntariness is about being free from external pressures, while capacity is about understanding and reasoning.

Option B: The participant's ability to understand the information provided and form a reasonable judgment.

This is the correct definition of capacity. It means that the individual must have the cognitive ability to understand the information presented and to make decisions based on a logical assessment of the possible consequences.

Option C: The participant's understanding of the risks and benefits of the research.

This is an element of disclosure and understanding, but it is not the definition of capacity itself. Capacity specifically involves the participant's cognitive ability to understand and make judgments.

Option D: The participant's willingness to participate in the research study.

Willingness is a part of voluntariness, not capacity. While an individual may be willing to participate, this does not necessarily reflect their ability to understand the risks or make informed judgments about the research.

choices.text: To ensure that the testator's estate plan is financially sound
To ensure that the testator is not being influenced by external pressures or coercion
To confirm that the testator has drafted the Will according to their personal preferences
To guarantee that the testator is legally represented during the Will creation process

questions.text: What is the primary purpose of assessing testamentary capacity?
questions.solution:
TESTAMENTARY CAPACITY

  • Definition: The mental ability to understand and sign a will, knowing the nature of one's assets, the beneficiaries, and the consequences.
  • Key Criteria (Bank vs Goodfellow case):
    • Understanding the nature and effects of the will.
    • Knowledge of the beneficiaries and their claims.
    • Free from delusions affecting asset distribution.
    • Clear, consistent expression of wishes regarding asset distribution.

Option A: To ensure that the testator's estate plan is financially sound.

The financial soundness of the estate plan is important but does not directly relate to testamentary capacity. The focus is on the testator's mental ability to make decisions.

Option B: To ensure that the testator is not being influenced by external pressures or coercion.

This is the correct answer. The main purpose of assessing testamentary capacity is to ensure the testator is making their decisions independently, without undue influence or coercion.

Option C: To confirm that the testator has drafted the Will according to their personal preferences.

While personal preferences are important, the focus is on the mental ability to make the decisions, not just ensuring the Will aligns with preferences.

Option D: To guarantee that the testator is legally represented during the Will creation process.

Legal representation is not a requirement for testamentary capacity. What matters is the testator's mental capacity and understanding of the Will's contents.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Important Elements for Valid Testamentary Capacity:

  • Act of Will-making: The testator must understand that they are making a Will.
  • Mental Understanding: Must understand the extent of their property and beneficiaries.
  • Free from External Influences: No undue influence, fraud, or coercion should affect decisions.
  • Clear Decision-making: The testator must be capable of making logical decisions regarding asset distribution.

choices.text: Statements are fully admissible in court
Statements are admissible only if recorded under supervision
Statements can be used to convict the accused

questions.text: What is the legal status of statements made during a narcoanalysis test in India?
questions.solution:
NARCOANALYSIS

  • Purpose: Primarily a deception detection technique, also known as the "truth serum" test.
  • Origin: Originally used in military settings, now employed in forensic investigations.
  • Principle: Uses barbiturates(e.g., Sodium Pentothal) to induce a semi-conscious state, lowering inhibitions and making it harder to lie.

Option A: Statements are fully admissible in court:

Narcoanalysis statements are not admissible in court due to their semi-conscious nature.

Option B: Statements are admissible only if recorded under supervision:

Even with supervision, narcoanalysis statements lack legal validity.

Option C: Statements have no legal validity:

Statements made during narcoanalysis are considered unreliable and inadmissible in court.

Option D: Statements can be used to convict the accused:

Statements obtained through narcoanalysis cannot be used as evidence for conviction due to concerns about their accuracy and voluntariness.

questions.text: Which of the following is a common form of asynchronous communication used in telemedicine?
questions.solution:
Asynchronous communication includes methods like email where information can be sent at one time and reviewed later, unlike real-time communication.

TELEMEDICINE & TELEPSYCHIATRY

  • Telemedicine covers multiple disciplines like radiology, dermatology, and psychiatry, with telepsychiatry being the most active in Western countries.
  • Telepsychiatry is defined as the use of ICT to provide psychiatric services across distances.
    • Now a rapidly developing field in telemedicine, second only to teleradiology.
  • Communication Models:
    • Synchronous (interactive): Real-time communication (e.g., video-conferencing, telephony).
      • Advantages: Immediate response, mimics face-to-face interaction.
    • Asynchronous (store and forward): Non-real-time, data sent for later review (e.g., e-mail).
      • Advantages: Low-cost, doesn't require simultaneous presence.
    • Applications of Telepsychiatry:
      • Clinical case management, consultation, diagnosis, follow-up, psychotherapy, and education.
      • Used for managing conditions like depression, schizophrenia, PTSD, etc.
      • Video-conferencing, internet-based CBT, and email consultations are commonly used.
    • Telepsychiatry Uses:
      • Psychotherapy for conditions like anxiety, depression, PTSD.
      • Neuropsychological assessments, crisis interventions, and therapy for special populations (e.g., veterans, prisoners, elderly).
    • Satisfaction and Feasibility:
      • Patients are generally satisfied with telepsychiatry, reporting no significant difference compared to face-to-face consultations.
      • Telepsychiatry is seen as cost-effective, with high satisfaction rates.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Asynchronous communication includes methods like email where information can be sent at one time and reviewed later, unlike real-time communication.

questions.text: Which of the following is most commonly associated with agitation in hospitalized patients?
questions.solution:
Agitation is often linked to cognitive disorders (e.g., delirium) or withdrawal from drugs such as opioids, alcohol, or sedative-hypnotics. Treatment typically includes sedation and careful evaluation for underlying causes like command hallucinations or paranoid ideation.

CONSULTATION-LIAISON PSYCHIATRY

  • Suicide Risk: Higher in patients with medical illness, particularly those with no social support, alcohol dependence, or severe pain. Requires psychiatric monitoring.
  • Depression: Must assess for suicidality; antidepressants should be prescribed carefully, considering drug interactions.
  • Agitation: Often due to cognitive disorders or drug withdrawal. Antipsychotics may help, physical restraints should be avoided.
  • Hallucinations: Common in delirium, alcohol withdrawal, or psychotic disorders. Treated with antipsychotics.
  • Sleep Disorders: Pain causes insomnia; depression links to early morning awakening, anxiety to falling asleep issues.
  • Confusion: Typically due to delirium. Antipsychotics help with agitation, but sedatives may worsen confusion.
  • Noncompliance: Can result from negative doctor-patient relationships or cognitive disorders. Legal competence may be needed.
  • Unexplained Symptoms: Consider psychiatric disorders like conversion, somatization, factitious disorders, or malingering when no medical cause is found.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is commonly associated with hallucinations in ICU patients?
questions.solution:
CONSULTATION-LIAISON PSYCHIATRY IN SPECIAL SITUATIONS:

Intensive Care Units (ICUs):

  • Patients in ICUs often experience anxiety, depression, and delirium due to high stress and traumatic events like cardiac arrests and medical disasters.
  • ICU staff, especially nurses, are also prone to burnout and high turnover due to psychological stress.
  • Support groups for ICU staff and house staff are recommended to manage stress and prevent psychiatric morbidity.

Hemodialysis Units:

  • Patients in hemodialysis units face chronic, debilitating conditions, requiring dependence on medical teams for life-sustaining dialysis treatments.
  • Dialysis, scheduled three times a week, disrupts patients' normal routines, leading to psychological strain.

Surgical Units:

  • Patients undergoing surgery who exhibit depression or anxiety but do not express it may have a higher risk of morbidity and mortality.
  • Positive attitudes and informed consent are important for improving surgical outcomes.
  • Patients should be educated on what to expect before and after surgery to reduce anxiety and improve recovery.

Transplantation Issues:

  • Psychiatrists help transplant patients and their families cope with emotional challenges, including anxiety, fear of organ rejection, and life post-transplant.
  • After transplantation, patients face challenges like medication adherence and managing psychiatric complications such as depression or PTSD.
  • Support groups and psychotherapy are essential for helping patients and organ donors cope with transplant-related stress.

Option A: Delirium tremens:

A severe alcohol withdrawal syndrome, often 3-4 days after hospitalization, causing hallucinations, agitation, and confusion.

Option B: Alcohol intoxication:

Alcohol intoxication causes impairment but not hallucinations.

Option C: Insomnia:

Insomnia leads to sleep issues but not hallucinations.

Option D: Severe depression:

Depression may cause mood changes but rarely causes hallucinations unless psychotic features are present.

questions.text: Which medication is considered first-line in the treatment of Delusional Parasitosis?
questions.solution:
Pimozide, a potent neuroleptic, is considered the most effective treatment for Delusional Parasitosis due to its dopamine antagonist properties. Other antipsychotic medications may also be used, but Pimozide is specifically noted for its efficacy.

DELUSIONAL PARASITOSIS

  • Characterized by a false belief of being infested with living organisms, typically bugs.

Differential Diagnosis:

  • Can mimic conditions like tuberculosis, syphilis, diabetes, dementia, and schizophrenia.

Neurobiology:

  • Linked to dopamine dysfunction and abnormal brain areas (putamen, striato-thalamocortical loop).

Patient Types:

  • Hypochondriacal: Believes in an incurable illness.
  • Paranoid: Focuses on fighting parasites.
  • Mixed: Exhibits both delusional traits.

Symptoms:

  • Repeated consultations, excessive cleaning, bringing specimens, and reluctance to accept psychiatric care.

Treatment:

  • Medications: Pimozide (most effective), other antipsychotics.
  • Adjuncts: Antidepressants, ECT.
  • Approach: Limited psychotherapy, focus on building a therapeutic relationship.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Characterized by a false belief of being infested with living organisms, typically bugs.

questions.text: Which of the following antidepressants is considered first-line treatment for depression in cancer patients?
questions.solution:
SSRIs are the first-line antidepressants for cancer patients due to their effectiveness, minimal sedative and autonomic side effects, and fewer drug interactions. They are well-tolerated and suitable for patients with cancer-related depression.

ROLE OF PSYCHIATRIST IN THE MANAGEMENT OF CANCER PATIENTS:

Pharmacological Therapy:

  • Depression: SSRIs are first-line treatment; psychostimulants can help with fatigue and appetite.
  • Bipolar Disorder: Mood stabilizers and neuroleptics can continue; caution with chemotherapy interactions.
  • Anxiety: Screen for depression; benzodiazepines for acute anxiety; long-term options like Buspirone.

ECT (Electroconvulsive Therapy):

  • Safe and effective for cancer patients, even with brain tumors.

Complementary & Alternative Medicine (CAM):

  • CAM therapies (acupuncture, yoga, etc.) can improve quality of life but not cure cancer.

Psychotherapeutic Approaches:

  • Crisis Intervention: Immediate support in life crises.
  • Psychological Counselling: Helps resolve adaptive difficulties.
  • Self-Support Groups: For emotional support (e.g., post-surgery).
  • Coping Skills, Guided Imagery, and Mindfulness: Help manage cancer-related stress and existential concerns.

Survivor Issues:

  • Concerns like recurrence, guilt, physical losses, and reintegration into normal life.

Oncologist Burnout:

  • Psychiatrists may help manage stress and burnout in oncology professionals.

Caregiver Burden:

  • High stress among caregivers may require psychiatric intervention.

Communication in Cancer Care:

  • Psychiatrists help train healthcare professionals in breaking bad news and handling patient-family dynamics.

questions.text: Which brain structures are most commonly affected in Korsakoff's syndrome, according to neuroimaging findings?
questions.solution:
Korsakoff's syndrome is characterized by atrophy of the mammillary bodies and thalamus, crucial for memory processing.

KORSAKOFF'S SYNDROME

  • Definition: A cognitive disorder characterized by severe memory impairment (particularly anterograde) in an otherwise alert patient, often associated with alcohol use and thiamine deficiency.
  • ICD-10 Classification: Alcohol-induced amnestic disorder.
  • DSM-5 Classification: Alcohol-induced major neurocognitive disorder (amnestic-confabulatory type, persistent).

Etiology

  • Main Cause: Severe thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency, most often from chronic alcohol consumption.
  • Other causes: Puerperal sepsis, gastric carcinoma, intractable vomiting, severe dietary deficiencies, etc.

Neuropathology

  • Key lesions: Mammillary bodies, anterior thalamic nuclei, and other brain structures.
  • Thiamine is critical for ATP production, myelin maintenance, and neurotransmitter function.

Neuroimaging

  • MRI shows atrophy of mammillary bodies, thalamus, and other brain regions involved in memory.

Clinical Features

  • Memory dysfunction: Anterograde memory is most affected; remote memory relatively spared.
  • Confabulation: Spontaneous or provoked, often linked to memory gaps.
  • Executive dysfunction: Affects planning, inhibition, working memory.
  • Apathy and emotion perception impairments are common.

Treatment

  • Primary Treatment: Thiamine replacement (IV or oral) to prevent progression.
  • Rehabilitation: Cognitive rehabilitation, memory aids (e.g., smartphones, smartwatches).
  • No pharmacological cure for established Korsakoff's syndrome.

questions.text: Which neurotransmitter system is most strongly associated with catatonia?
questions.solution:
CATATONIA

  • Definition: Catatonia is a severe motor syndrome, first described by Karl Kahlbaum in 1874.
  • Historically, catatonia was associated with schizophrenia as a phase of dementia precox, but it is now considered a syndrome that can occur in multiple psychiatric and medical conditions.

Aetiopathogenesis:

  • Neurochemical Factors:
    • GABA: Dysregulation of GABAergic transmission is a key feature. Benzodiazepines (which enhance GABA) are effective in treating catatonia, suggesting involvement of GABA-A receptors.
    • Glutamate: Hyperactivity of NMDA receptors may contribute to catatonia, explaining the efficacy of NMDA antagonists like Memantine in resistant cases.
  • Seizure Model: Seizure-like mechanisms are thought to play a role, as post-ictal immobility shares similarities with catatonia.
    • Status epilepticus(non-convulsive or partial complex) can manifest with catatonia.
    • Anticonvulsants and ECT (Electroconvulsive therapy) can help manage catatonia.
  • Motor Circuitry Dysfunction: Involvement of the frontal lobe and basal ganglia, which regulate motor activity and behaviour, may explain the motor disturbances in catatonia.
  • Fear Model: Trauma-induced catatonia may represent a "frozen" state in response to extreme fear or stress.
  • Immune Model: Anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis has been associated with catatonic symptoms, highlighting the role of the immune system in certain cases. Other autoimmune conditions like PANDAS, lupus cerebritis, and APLAS can also cause catatonia.

Principal Signs in Catatonia:

  • Mutism: Lack of verbal response, not always associated with immobility.
  • Stupor: Severe lack of responsiveness, hypoactivity, and altered arousal; may not react even to painful stimuli.
  • Posturing: Holding abnormal positions for extended periods (e.g., grimacing, "prayer-like" postures).
  • Waxy Flexibility: Resistance to being moved, followed by passive compliance (like bending a wax figure).
  • Negativism (Gegenhalten): Patient resists any attempt to move them.
  • Stereotypy: Repetitive, non-goal-directed motor behaviour (e.g., repetitive phrases or movements).
  • Automatic Obedience: Performing actions that the examiner directs, even if contrary to instructions.
  • Ambitendency: Difficulty deciding or moving between contradictory signals (e.g., conflicting handshakes).
  • Echophenomena:
  • Echolalia: Repeating words or phrases.
  • Echopraxia: Mimicking movements.

questions.text: Which drug is considered the first-line treatment for catatonia?
questions.solution:
CATATONIA MANAGEMENT

Management:

  • General Measures:
    • Provide a safe environment for the patient.
    • Monitor vitals and hydration status.
    • Feeding support via NG tube if patient is uncooperative.
  • Specific Treatment:
    • Benzodiazepines(e.g., Lorazepam) are the first-line treatment.
    • Dosing: Typically start at 4mg/day, can escalate to 8-24mg/day.
    • Neuroleptics(Olanzapine, Clozapine) can be used if psychosis is suspected.
    • ECT: Considered for life-threatening cases.
    • For NMS: Discontinue antipsychotics, follow NMS protocol with Benzodiazepines and ECT.

Mechanism of Action of Benzodiazepines in Catatonia:

  • GABAergic transmission: Benzodiazepines enhance GABA activity, improving motor and cognitive symptoms.
  • BDNF reduction: Reduces Brain Derived Neurotrophic Factor, which may play a role in neuronal protection.

Prognosis:

  • Good prognosis with early and aggressive treatment, especially for mood disorders.
  • The prognosis in schizophrenia is generally less favourable.
  • High-dose Lorazepam(up to 24mg/day) improves outcomes significantly.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: rTMS (repetitive Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation): An emerging treatment for Lorazepam-resistant catatonia, showing promise in clinical trials.
